title: Disabled pregnant woman finds cruel note calling her "fat lazy c***" after parking in parent and child space
text:

A disabled woman who is almost eight months pregnant has revealed how an angry driver called her a "fat lazy c***" in an abusive note left on her car. 
The cruel message was found by the 33-year-old mum-to-be after she parked in a parent and child space outside a supermarket. 
The woman, who uses a walking stick, decided to park in one of the unused spots after she was unable to find a disabled space. 
She displayed her blue badge and went inside, but was left shocked when she and her partner returned 30 minutes later and found the offensive letter left on the windscreen. The pregnant woman says she was left shocked and disgusted (Photo: Guzelian) 
The note left by an anonymous driver read: "These spaces are for people with children not for fat lazy c**** or 'disabled'. Spaz spaces are behind." Read More 
It was left on the woman's car outside Morrisons on Swinnow Road in Leeds at around 3:15pm on Monday. 
The woman, who suffered a stroke at 23, said: "I was shocked, disgusted and left feeling vulnerable. Facebook users offered support after the woman posted this message (Photo: Guzelian) 
"The level of hate used in this note for something I as a heavily pregnant women is entitled to use as well as my mobility issues. 
"I went back into the store and the woman on the customer service desk read the note and was as shocked as me. 
"I'm left feeling saddened that people in this day and age have such hatred for people they don't understand and how they described disabled people as 'spaz' spaces." 
She added: "I would have had some respect if this person would have just asked why I had parked in that spot instead of assuming that I didn't actually need it or wasn't entitled to use it. The woman parked in a parent and child spot because the disabled spaces were full (Photo: Getty) Read More Couple get death threats after 'charging customer for cancelling cleaning appointment when she suffered miscarriage' 
"It's left me feeling upset to the point that I don't want to go out on my own and this has a knock on effect on my family." 
The woman posted a photo of the note to a community group on Facebook and was overwhelmed with the number of supportive responses from people. 
Many wrote that they were disgusted by the language used in the letter and felt the whole note was unnecessary. Like us on Facebook
